entry.title: Gallery
entry.content:
Mostly rocks, sometimes not ‚Äî here are my favorite photos of people, places, and landscapes.

üí° Recommended: click into images for a spotlight view üí°
entry.summary: Some of my favorite shots across the years

entry.title: Indian Creek 2025
entry.content:
Back to the Creek! We only spent a week there this time but we made the most of it. It was especially great to be down there with good friends. Having been there alone once before I wouldn‚Äôt have it any other way.


Beginnings

With the rack secured, cams labeled, and a promising weather forecast, all that was left to do was drive 18 hours! Fortunately we got to break it up by seeing Jack's sister in Ketchum, ID.



Pistol Whipped

On our first day we went to Pistol Whipped. I warmed up on Spaghetti Western which turns out isn't a warm up, but it may be my favorite climb in the creek. The climbing was varied with a middle section that featured a 30-foot, overhanging hand crack! We also climbed Revenge of the Rock Gods and Jolly Rancher, the latter of which was well deserving of the hype and fortunately reached with our 78.5 meter rope.


Spaghetti Western

Jack getting stoked, me trying not to pump out on the "warm up"

Jolly Rancher, sun avoidance, and we're hungry for more!


2nd Meat Wall

This was my favorite wall we went to this trip! It was relatively uncrowded and has a high concentration of quality routes!

Me on Mouse Meat and Ilana on Tofu Crack.


Ilana on Evening Ecstasy.

Send train! Jack on Tofu, Max on Top Sirloin, Me on Top Sirloin


Katie P on Extra Lean.

Such a great day!

Sparks Wall

I had really been looking forward to visiting this crag and I think it was a bit underwhelming. Big crowds, not a ton of moderate climbs...still a fun day, just not what I expected. We warmed up on Skraps, then climbed Jump Start and Sparkling Gefilte Fish, and after a lot of waiting I was eventaully able to get on Go Sparky Go for an onsite. A fun day but I probably won't be going back to this crag unless I'm feeling ready to send Old Sparky.


Warren on Jupiter

Me on Go Sparky Go. Warren took pics of me at every part except the crux üòÇ


Amazing hangs at camp!

Fin Wall

After warming up on Walkin Talkin Bob, Jack T and I climbed The Last Day by accident thinking it was Double Trouble. According to the Mountain Project comments, Mason Earle made the same mistake in 2007. I finished the day on Nagasaki which was a ton of fun.


Nagasaki


Creek-o-ween rave! üéÉ

Optimator

I really wanted to go back to Optimator to send Soulfire and Annunaki and maybe climb Neat. Even though we made it up early, the only party that beat us was, of course, already on Neat ‚Äî and putting out bad vibes besides. I warmed up on Soulfire and fell at the top again (classic). The crowds quickly thickened and lots of people aided up Annunaki while I sat at the base waiting for a redpoint attempt. I even climbed Lady Pillar while waiting. Not exactly the experience I wanted, but in the end I sent Annunaki without any trouble which made it feel worth it, if barely. I then climbed Caseys and belayed Jack T on Cobweb Splitter and Hayutake after yet more shennanigans with the crowds. This was a great reminder that the scene in the creek can be overwhelming and it's generally worth going to less-popular crags when you can. I'll always love Optimator, but I probably won't be going back soon!

Me and Jack T on the Annunaki send train


Jack sending Cobweb Splitter

Celebrating Jack T's 30th birthday with Key Lime pie!


Somewhere near Boise


18 hours later ‚Äî with red sand in our shoes and desert sun in our hearts ‚Äî and we landed back in wet, dark Washington! Our hopes that the snows would be soon to follow were shortly squandered and left us swearing to a longer trip next year!$$

entry.title: Sardinia & Chamonix 2025
entry.content:
‚ö†Ô∏è If you‚Äôre here for rock climbing content skip to the Chamonix section! ‚ö†Ô∏è

The main purpose of this trip was to go to Jack‚Äôs brother‚Äôs wedding in Amalfi. We then went to Sardinia where we did a little bit of sport climbing and a lot of driving / swimming. Finally we stopped in Chamonix for some alpine climbing. Not a rock-forward trip but still a ton of fun!

Whitefish

This trip actually began with a wedding in Whitefish, MT. We got to ride the Whitefish bike park while we were there which was extremely fun.

Amalfi

Only one day later we were off to Amalfi for Jack's brother's wedding üòµ‚Äçüí´ I was so focused on climbing later in the trip that I didn't know what to expect in Amalfi. Safe to say I was blown away. Smashed up against the cliffs south of Naples, Amalfi became one of the major maritime republics of the middle ages and is now a tourist hotbed ‚Äî you can see why!

The Washington crew was relieved to be in Italy (and no longer in transit)

I've done some sketchy rappels and been close to large rockfall events, but driving scooters around blind corners with oncoming tour busses on a single-lane road was the scariest thing I've ever done.

Wedding warm-up! And what a show it was!

Sardinia

We knew well before going to Sardinia that it was going to be pretty hot for climbing, but still we underestimated! It was oppressively hot. We still got out climbing a couple times and also got to drive an Italian sports car and a boat around the island.

Chamonix

We headed to cooler temps in Chamonix and were immediately rewarded with stunning views from the Mer du Glace glacier. Walking out of the house with all our gear and taking the bus, to the train, to the gondola, to the glacier, to the via ferrata, to the Envers hut left us feeling giddy. I don't know if the Euros do it right but they do it different ‚Äî and whatever else it is it's very rad.

Car to plane to bus to train...

Aguille de Dru and glacier crossing

Coming up the via ferrata

Before a night in the hut vs after a night in the hut


Sunrise over the Mer du Glace

Starting up the classic crack climb, Guy Anne L'Insolite

Jack following the mental crux on pitch 3 and leading his first alpine pitch (5)

Last pitch on Guy Anne

Looking back at the spectacular finger crack of pitch (4)


The Refuge de l'Envers des Aiguilles (left side)

Woke up to an interesting surprise for our hike out!

It rained over our last few days so weren't able to climb more, but we had some amazing food back in town! Next time we'll climb BEFORE the September wedding üòÑ


One flight later and we were back in WA to harvest the tomatoes!
entry.summary: 2 weeks of weddings and climbing in Italy and France

entry.title: Squamish 2025
entry.content:
Back to Squamish! Not only do I love the granite, but also the food, weather, and general amenities. This summer Jack and I spent two long weekends there, but neither was long enough!

Jack styling the Burglar and the Reacharound, respectively. Aesthetically they look like twin routes, but the former is all face holds while the latter is a crack climb.

Jack traversing up the Hairpin ‚Äî seems he enjoyed it!

Jack enjoying the scenic backdrop.

Time for donuts!

Throne of Moss

Unknown climber on Apron Strings.

Jack dancing back and forth up the perfect finger crack of the Exasperator.

The final reach!

Bring your bike to crag day üòµ‚Äçüí´

"I have to lunge for THAT?!?" Slap and Tickle.

The Grand Wall!

We hustled our way up Slot Machine, Ma√±ana, and Bullethead East before swim time!

Turns out biking in Squamish is kind of sandbagged! Jack walking some of the techy stuff on Leave of Absence.

entry.title: Yosemite 2025
entry.content:
This spring I got to take my first climbing trip to Yosemite Valley. Over a couple weeks I got to climb many classic routes including Astroman, Royal Arches, Serenity-Sons, Freeblast, and Lurking Fear. Overall, the Valley met my expectations: Starbucks, crowds, and beginner climbers alongside the highest concentration of quality granite and crusher climbers I‚Äôve ever seen.

El Capitan ‚Äî can you spot the parties climbing the wall? There are at least 4!

Astroman! THE free climb of the Valley. We got absolutely wrecked by the infamous Harding Slot, but had so much fun.

Biking past 2,000 ft waterfalls on our way to 2,000 ft rock climbs??? What a treat!

Jack Taylor on the Royal Arches.

Jack, soaking it in!

The ditch! As seen from the prow of WA Column.

WA Column, Half Dome, the splitter cracks of Serenity-Sons, and (finally) a rest day!

Me working up the first pitch of the Freeblast!
Jack on pitch 4 and me on Heart Ledge. What an awesome route! I did not quite onsight but had a "blast"!

Looking back up at Heart Ledges. ü©∂

Lurking Fear! My first ever big wall climb. Everyone asks about sleeping on the portaledge, but that was easy compared to hauling the pigs!

Day 2 on Lurking fear.

Our final bivvy and top out! A great time with a great friend.
entry.summary: 10 days of climbing in Yosemite, CA

entry.title: Washington 2025
entry.content:
It was a great winter! I stayed local since I was taking care of Jack who was unable to do much post meniscus surgery. I got to take the sled out a few times, ski at WA Pass, in the Teanaway, and at Holden Village! I especially liked skiing around the Tye Peak zone this year for some reason. There‚Äôs always a different ‚Äúfavorite‚Äù zone; this year I was liking the ease of access, diversity in terrain options, lack of crowds (if you know where to go), and pockets of deep powder. I‚Äôm most excited to ski in the Teanaway next year since it has all those things but better.

Early Season

The first few tours of the season! A couple resort tours, lots of time up the Icicle, a too-early Stormies lap ‚Äî classic!

Birthday Tour



Aerials

Epic views from the plane!

Long's Pass



Holden Village



Colchuck Glacier

entry.title: Alpine Rafting
entry.content:
Nothing is better than floating in an alpine lake!

You can see right to the bottom, which sort of makes it feel like if you fall out of the boat, you‚Äôre gonna fall 100 feet!
